I.  THE ENSUING PROJECT 
 
1.  Hydro Developments Pty Ltd (Hydro Developments), via its 100% subsidiary, Hydro 
Taveuni Pte Ltd, has been shortlisted in a tender by Energy Fiji Limited (EFL) for an independent 
power producer (IPP) to provide up to 45 gigawatt-hours per annum of renewable energy to Vanua 
Levu, Fiji’s second largest island, and neighboring island Taveuni. The Project will consist of two 
run-of-river hydropower units to be built on Taveuni, Lavena (up to 4 megawatts [MW]) and 
Salialevu (2MW), serving a population approaching 36,000 people who currently rely on diesel 
power generation.1 The project also includes 75km of 33 kilovolt (kV) transmission connecting 
power generation on Taveuni, 9km of subsea cable to connect Taveuni transmission to the 
adjacent island of Vanua Levu, and 115km of 66kV transmission on Vanua Levu to connect to 
EFL’s existing grid. ADB may participate in the expected subsequent financing of the approximate 
$40 million capital cost (including transmission) required to build the project. 
 
2.  The Fiji Government, under the 2017 National Development Plan,2 has a goal for 100% of 
Fijians to have access to electricity before December 2022 (currently 96%),3 with 81% of this 
electricity to be supplied from renewable sources, increasing to 100% by 2030.4 The Government 
also has a goal of 30 percent reduction of carbon emissions from the energy sector by 2030.5 
Currently, approximately 45% of Fiji’s power needs are supplied through fossil fuels, 50% through 
hydropower,  and  the  remaining  5%  from  biomass  and  wind  power.6 The  project  is  being 
developed with the strong support and involvement of the local “Mataqali” or indigenous clan, and 
there will be no displacement of communities. 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
3.  The technical assistance (TA) transaction of $500,000, to be implemented over a 15-
month period (October 2021–December 2022), will be provided to Hydro Developments to assist 
Hydro Developments and EFL to complete the project feasibility study. Hydro Developments 
conducted extensive project survey and pre-feasibility work over 2019-21, followed in Q3 2021 
by engineering feasibility study work by Australian consultancy AEP Elical funded by $500,000 
[CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED].7 Preliminary feasibility study conclusions including 
estimated power tariff costs will be submitted to EFL for its Board consideration of the proposed 
independent power producer (IPP). 
 
4.  Should EFL request Hydro Developments to proceed with its IPP proposal, further TA 
support is needed due to relatively large areas of land, including sub-sea terrain, that need to be 
examined for environmental feasibility, and expert environmental and legal opinions are essential 
to complete the project feasibility study exercise. The TA will also build the capacity of Hydro 
Developments to administer the ensuing Project and ensure Project readiness for implementation 
once a commercial IPP power purchase agreement is negotiated with EFL.

C.  Cost and Financing 
 
6.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000 which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF)-Income Transfer.8  The TA will fund two consulting 
contracts,  the  project  environmental  impact  study  and  project  legal  services,  with  the  key 
expenditure items listed in Appendix 1. 
 
7.  The TA will include full recovery of the amount financed under the TA if the project 
sponsors are subsequently able to raise the necessary capital to build the project. 
 
8.  Hydro Developments will fund in parallel additional project development costs (estimated 
at  $315,000,  including  in-kind  contribution)  including  staff  costs.  [CONFIDENTIAL 
INFORMATION DELETED]. Hydro Developments has been informed that approval of the TA 
does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project.

E.  Governance

1.   TERMS OF REFERENCE 
 
A.  Environmental and Social Impact Assessment 
 
1.  PROJECT BACKGROUND AND OBJECTIVES 
Hydro Developments Pty Ltd (Hydro Developments) is participating in a tender with Energy Fiji 
Limited (EFL) to provide up to 55 GigaWatt hours per annum of renewable energy from Taveuni 
Island via two to-be-built hydropower units called Lavena and Salialevu (the Project), serving a 
population  approaching  36,000  people  currently  relying  predominantly  on  diesel  power 
generation. 
 
The Lavena subproject involves diversion of water from Wainisairi Creek at an elevation of 
approximately 285m above sea level, The creek, impoundment and weir, pipeline, penstock, and 
powerhouse areas are all reportedly located within land owned by the Mataqali Matakuro, with 
whom a land lease has been signed.  
 
The Salialevu subproject involves diversion of water from Drekeniwailevu Creek near the eastern 
boundary of the Salialevu Estate and running this water through a pipeline with a length of 
approximately 1,600m to a power plant located close to sea level, about 2,000m northeast of 
Salialevu village. A subsidiary intake located on adjacent crown land will increase the output from 
the Project.   
 
The outputs from the two plants will be delivered to a substation near Waiyevo Village by means 
of 33kV transmission lines with total length 75km. A 9km submarine cable would be built from a 
proposed 11/33kV sub-station at Waiyevo across the Somosomo Strait to Vatudamu Point in the 
southeast of Vanua Levu. A new 66kV overhead transmission line of 115km is proposed for 
Vanua Levu.

7 
The Project is being considered for financing by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and as such 
the Company requires the services of an independent environmental and social consultant (“the 
Consultant”)  to  develop  a  Project  ESIA  and  ESMP  including  associated  facilities  such  as 
accesses, rainfall and flow measurement installations, bathymetyric and other surveys and, if 
determined to be required, additional assessments and plans to ensure the Project is compliant 
against the Assessment Framework. 
2.  ASSESSMENT FRAMEWORK 
The following standards are the Assessment Framework against which this scope of work is to 
be undertaken: 
  Applicable local, and national environmental and social laws and regulations of Fiji relating 
to concessions, land acquisition and resettlement, labor and working conditions, public 
and occupational health and safety, ethnic groups/indigenous peoples and environmental 
protection, to obtain and update Government approval for the Project; 
  ADB Safeguard Policy Statement (SPS) (2009); 
  ADB Social Protection Strategy (2001); 
  ADB Gender and Development Policy (1998); 
  ADB Access to Information Policy (2019); 
  World  Bank  Group/IFC  (2018)  Good  Practice  Handbook  Environmental  Flows  for 
Hydropower Projects. Guidance for the Private Sector in Emerging Markets;  
  World Bank Group/IFC (2018) Good Practice Note Environmental, Health, and Safety 
Approaches for Hydropower Projects; 
  World Bank Group Sector Environmental, Health and Safety Guidelines for Electric Power 
Transmission and Distribution, (April 2007); 
  World Bank Group/IFC (2013) Good Practice Handbook Cumulative Impact Assessment 
and Management: Guidance for the Private Sector in Emerging Markets; 
  IFC/EBRD Workers’ accommodation: processes and standards. A guidance note by IFC 
and the EBRD (2009); 
  World  Bank  Group  /IFC  (2007)  Environmental,  Health,  and  Safety  (EHS)  General 
Guidelines;  
  Relevant international treaties to which Fiji is a signatory such as (but is not limited to) the 
UN  Declaration  on  the  Rights  of  Indigenous  Peoples,  International  Covenant  on 
Economic, Cultural and Social Rights and International Labor Organization (ILO) Core 
Conventions, all other ILO Conventions ratified by Fiji;  
  Interim Advice for IFC and EBRD Clients on Migrant Workers and COVID-19; and 
  Interim Advice for IFC Clients on Preventing and Managing Health Risks of COVID-19 in 
the Workplace. 
 
3.  SCOPE OF WORK  
ADB requires an environmental and social impact assessment in accordance with Safeguard 
Policy Statement (2009) requirements for the Project and all Associated Facilities.  The scope is 
provided below in 2 phases, detailed by task. The Consultant should respond to the scope in their 
proposal, highlighting any additional tasks that may be required.

8 
Phase 1:  Desk Review and Scoping Study 
 
An Initial Environmental Evaluation is currently being undertaken as part of the Phase A feasibility 
study being prepared by Hydro Developments for submission to EFL. A Screening Application is 
also being prepared for submission to the Fiji Department of Environment. This work will form part 
of a scoping report to be submitted to ADB including methodology development, following a 
desktop review and gap assessment. The scoping report will need to be reviewed by ADB and 
should include a review of all existing documentation, detailed Project reports, concession 
agreements, government order/awards relating to land/RoW acquisition available for the Project 
and other relevant documentation. The purpose of the review is to get an understanding of the 
Project and associated impacts and identify gaps with respect to the Project’s Assessment 
Framework. This review will include areas such as social, poverty and gender assessments, land 
acquisition  and  resettlement,  biodiversity  assessments,  environmental  flows  assessments, 
stakeholder engagement, labor and working conditions, cumulative impact assessments, noise 
and vibration assessments, safety risk assessment, natural hazards, climate risk assessment, 
water resources and spring hazards assessment, and contractor management, among others. It 
is expected that the desk review will help in identifying data/information needs and streamline the 
approach and methodology for the ESIA consistent with Project requirements. 
  
Specifically, this phase of the work will entail the following:   
  Review of the Project’s (including any Associated Facilities) existing environmental, social and 
gender  documentation  (including  environmental  and  social  management  plans),  if  any, 
against the Assessment Framework. This assessment will be based on the review of available 
documents, and discussion with relevant individuals, and may result in recommendations for 
improvement to existing documents, baseline surveys, or supporting studies. This review 
should include (but not be limited to) the review of the following: 
o  Potential direct, indirect, cumulative, and induced impacts and risks to physical, biological, 
and physical cultural resources in the context of the Project’s area of influence. 
o  The analysis of alternatives and complement as necessary including non-hydropower 
energy  generation  options,  and  technology  and  operation  alternatives  and  their 
corresponding environmental and social impacts.  
o  The environmental and social baseline data and identify research or supplemental studies 
required to address data gaps or ensure its validity.  
o  The coverage, methods, and results of geological, bathymetric, hydrogeological and 
geohazards and landslide risks investigations performed to date and determine and justify 
the need for additional field surveys to enable the assessment of impacts associated with 
Project activities (in particular tunneling and blasting) on households, springs and other 
relevant infrastructure.  
o  Biodiversity baseline information available from primary and secondary sources that 
clarifies whether any of the following species may occur in the Project area and, if so, 
whether it is likely that the area meets Critical Habitat thresholds for each species in 
reference to IFC Performance Standard 6 Guidance Notes (2019) – in particular: (i) 
globally or nationally critically endangered, endangered, or vulnerable species; and (ii)

9 
endemic, or restricted-range species. Particular attention should be paid to plants, snails, 
and freshwater biodiversity1. 
o  Available hydrological flow and sediment data, coastal and river morphology, water users 
and uses (including upstream and downstream dams), freshwater and marine biota and 
spawning area information to identify any gaps, and determine the potential extent of 
downstream operation impacts, and any additional baseline data collection necessary to 
prepare a suitable eFlows assessment following good international industry practice. 
o  The coverage of the socio-economic survey or census to confirm the extent to which it 
covered all communities or villages potentially affected by pre-construction, construction 
and operational activities of the Project and whether vulnerable groups and individuals 
have been identified. 
o  Cultural heritage information including if an assessment was done covering tangible and 
intangible cultural heritage. 
o  Environmental and social impacts (permanent or temporary) and proposed mitigation 
measures  in  existing  environmental  and  social  documents  available  to  date,  and 
determine whether: (i) all potential environmental and social risks and impacts (including 
upon ecosystem services) from the construction and operation of the Project and its

o  Proposed monitoring activities in the government approved EIA, if any, and determine if 
these: (i) are commensurate with the Project's risk and impacts and consistent with the 
findings of the environmental assessment and mitigation measures in the ESMP; (ii)

  Review  processes,  procedures,  and  the  institutional  capacity  (including  the  Company’s

  Review of Project’s strategy to accommodate the recommendations and/or requirements (if

  Review of the Company’s management system and practices with regard to national labor

  Review  and  confirm  the  adequacy  of  E&S  clauses  in  the  various  contract  documents 
(including EPC) and the obligations of the sub-contractors with respect to the Assessment

  Review  of  existing  gender  practices  and  assess  gender  dimensions  of  key  social  and

  Review whether the Project involves any child protection risks. 
The assessment process will be commensurate with, and proportional to, the potential risks, 
aspects and impacts of the Project avoiding any unnecessary duplication of efforts, and will cover, 
in an integrated manner, all relevant direct, indirect & cumulative environmental and social 
aspects and impacts of the Project, and the relevant stages of the Project cycle (e.g., pre-
construction, construction, and operation). The outcome of Phase I would be a concise gaps 
assessment and scoping report that will include refined approaches/methodologies for the 
supplementary studies (i.e., a detailed work plan). Following the review and approval of the 
detailed work plan, the Consultant shall undertake supplementary studies and prepare additional 
environmental and social management plans and systems as required to meet the Assessment 
Framework. 
 
Phase 2a: Environmental and Social Impact Assessment 
The activities to be undertaken as part of this phase will be determined by the outcome of Phase 
1. Data collected as part of the initial assessments that is of sufficient quality should be used, 
where appropriate, to avoid duplication of effort. All enhanced documentation will be reviewed 
and approved by the Company and ADB. It is envisaged that this work may entail: 
  Modifications to  the  existing  baseline  surveys and/or the  conduct  of additional  surveys 
(including those related to biodiversity and socioeconomics), other supporting studies or 
accompanying maps and figures; 
  Modifications to the existing studies and management plans and/or the conduct of additional 
assessments  and  plans  regarding  land  acquisition  /  allocation  and  indigenous 
peoples/minority ethnic groups (including a Social Compliance Audit for prior activities and 
impacts, as applicable, and determined and agreed in Phase 1); 
  Modifications  to  existing  and/or  the  development  of  additional  Environmental,  Social, 
Occupational Health & Safety, Community Health & Safety management plans, and Project 
Company and EPC labor standards and procedures; and 
  Modifications  to  existing  and/or  the  development  of  additional  gender  assessments  on 
women’s economic and social empowerment in the context of the Project and highlight key 
opportunities for the Project to address existing local gender equality gaps.

ary schematic diagrams for reference.  Similarly, the Project’s dewatered segment during op
erations should be clearly described, as well as the expected operational mode (e.g., true ru
n-of-river, etc.) minimum flows and drawings and maps showing the Project’s layout and com
ponents, the Project site and area of influence should be provided. 
  Legislative and Regulatory Requirement: The Consultant shall identify and describe the p
ertinent regulations and standards - both local and international, governing the environmenta
l quality, health and safety, protection of sensitive areas, land use control at the national and 
local levels, gender equality, and ecological and socio-economic issues. Thereafter, the Con
sultant shall identify the Project activities that should comply with the identified regulations. 
  Description of the Baseline Environment:2 The Consultant is required to review, collect, c
ollate, and present baseline information on the environmental characteristics of the Project’s 
area of influence. This description should involve but not be limited to physical, biological, an
d socio-economic parameters, resource base, and infrastructure. The assessment should de
lineate and cover the Project impact areas (primary and secondary/induced impacts). The de
scription of the environmental and social baseline data includes (but is not limited to) the foll
owing: 
o  River Use:  
  The description of downstream water, river uses (existing and future) and discharge
s should be included in the ESIA and supported by survey data.  
  A sample survey of households likely to be affected (directly by loss of land or a res
ult of Project related development including cumulative developments in the river ba
sin) as a part of the social assessment should be undertaken to confirm existing use
s (e.g., domestic water supply for part of the year, fishing, irrigation, ceremonial, cult
ural or recreational uses) with the objective of ensuring that these uses will be maint
ained, provided for by another means, or compensated for.  
  If there is seasonal use of the river, then the surveys conducted should take this into
 account. 
 
2  Please note that it is very important that any additional baseline data to be collected is well conceived and the 
sampling methodology well defined. Before engaging in any extensive geomorphological, physical, hydrological, 
biological or social surveys the Consultant should clearly define the questions expected to be answered. For 
instance, any additional social surveys should be guided by the Land Acquisition, Involuntary Resettlement and 
Livelihood Restoration Plan (RAP), or any additional aquatic and riparian or hydro-morphological data should be 
guided by the data needed to define an adequate downstream flow regime. Therefore, we do not expect extensive 
biological or social surveys without a clear purpose, and any new data should have a clear well stated objective 
and targeted to propose management measure for specific impact/ risks.

13 
  River uses should be assessed in four different segments of the river: (a) Upstream 
from the expected reservoir, (b) all flooded areas, (c) the de-watered segment, and (
d) downstream of the powerhouse.   
o  Biophysical Aspects: 
  Regional geology, Project specific geology, and seismic hazards studies. 
  Topography and bathymetry of the Project area of influence. 
  Hydrological and meteorological data. 
  Geo-morphological aspects such as catchment stability, sediment load, sediment tra
nsport, erosion management / soil permeability. 
  Erosion, landslides historical records and expected risks. 
  Climate change risk assessment. 
o  Biological Resources (Terrestrial, Freshwater and Marine Ecology):  
  Completion of a full marine survey to identify the features on the sea floor for the wh
ole length of the cable. Video surveys used to provide an overview of conditions in t
he Project’s impact areas. 
  Assessment of whether the Project impact areas are located near or within environm
entally sensitive areas.  The location of these sensitive areas should be reflected in 
maps of the Project context. 
  Methodologies for data gathering, mapping, surveys, sampling and special studies - 
terrestrial (vegetation/flora/fauna and terrestrial wildlife), aquatic (e.g., fish/fishery su
rvey/benthic organisms/coral) within the primary and secondary impact areas should
 be described.  Seasonal sampling and analysis should be undertaken.   
  Habitats within the Project area should be characterized and mapped as modified, n
atural or critical based on ADB SPS definitions.  
  The results of the terrestrial and aquatic survey and studies should note any threate
ned species or habitats, endemic/restricted range species, geographically- restricted
 species assemblages or habitats, migratory and/or congregatory species (including 
fish breeding grounds), and key ecosystem services.  
  The current status of threats to biodiversity - notably invasive species of flora and 
fauna – should be identified in the Project impact areas. 
  If preliminary data indicates that the Project may be considered to be within a Critica
l Habitat, then a Critical Habitat Assessment should be an integral component of the
 ESIA. 
  Appropriate maps, figures, graphs and diagrams should be provided for ease of refe

14 
rence, e.g., land use map of the Project area, survey areas, etc.  
o  Surface Water Quality, Air Quality and Noise Levels: 
  The ESIA will delineate all Project impact areas (primary and secondary impact area
s), and also identify socially sensitive receptors e.g., school, hospitals, residential, te
mples, or other sites of religious, cultural, heritage or aesthetic value etc. that existin
g within the Project areas.  Roads, transmission lines, spoil disposal areas, quarries 
and any associated facility should be included in the Project area of influence.  
  Methodologies for data gathering, sampling, analysis and modeling (if required). In a
ddition to standard water quality methods, BMWP-type biological metrics should be 
considered.  
  Results of laboratory testing and interpretation (e.g., surface water, air quality, and n
oise levels) should be presented and compared against the local and international e
nvironmental standards and those required under WBG EHS General Guidelines an
d relevant ADB requirements. 
  Location maps, figures, graphs, and diagrams should be provided for ease of refere
nce. 
o  Groundwater and Springs:  
  The study will delineate Project impact areas (primary and secondary impacts) likely
 to be affected by the construction and operations such as: (i) ground water, water w
ells, and springs along the tunnel alignment; (ii) springs and wells along access road
s, quarries and other ancillary facilities; (iii) springs and wells that could be affected 
by flooding; and (iv) springs and wells along the dewatered segment.  Community u
sage and impacts on these ground water springs and water bodies would also be de
termined/baseline assessed and impacts along with mitigation measures delineated. 
o  Economic, Social and Cultural Aspects: 
  Baseline sex-disaggregated socio-economic profile of the communities in the Projec
t area and dependencies on common community property and resources. 
  Land ownership, land use, and any land legacy issues within the area to be affected
 and acquired by the Project. 
  Existing vulnerabilities. 
  Sex-disaggregated socio-economic and cultural information on the potential host co
mmunities for resettled population (if identified). 
  Data on employment, identifying existing skills of the labor force. 
  Brief description of the potential workforce that will be brought to the site, from const
ruction to operations.

15 
  Potential impact/s of the Project on the local labor market and labor-market-related a
ctions that can be taken in the Project to address various labor-related risks, includin
g lack of adherence to the core labor standards. 
  Dependence (economic, social, cultural) on the marine environment as well as the ri
ver and water bodies linked to the river basin in the area, including – as much as po
ssible – quantification of ecosystem services which may be impacted by the Project. 
  Health condition of the Project affected population. 
  Infrastructure and amenities. 
  Any other sensitive social receptors in the area which could have links to the Project
 including local community gender norms and inequality status; local community pre
valence of gender-based violence; sexual exploitation, abuse and harassment affect
ing women and children; and risks to child protection. This assessment requires me
etings and interviews with women’s focus groups and other relevant stakeholders.  
o  Gender Analysis: 
  Gender sensitive data collection and baseline information on women’s economic an
d social empowerment in the context of the Project, including gender differentiations
 in access to education and healthcare, skills levels, roles and responsibilities in the 
communities, and economic occupations. 
  Identification of gender dimensions of key social and institutional issues in relation to
 Project objectives and key opportunities for the Project to address existing local gen
der equality gaps. 
  Gender assessment of the Project Company, with analysis of the organizational prof
ile of the Company and how gender equality is considered by the Company. 
  Analysis of Alternatives: This section should cover the economic, technical, environmental
, and social issues that were considered for each major design feature where they apply, pro
viding justification for the selected sites, designs and operating regime, and describe the maj
or impact mitigation measures. Alternative options, particularly for location and design of Pro
ject infrastructure, should include (as much as possible quantitative) assessment of both fina
ncial costs of such alternatives and costs/benefits from a social and environmental perspecti
ve, to contribute to a comprehensive analysis that demonstrates that the overall benefits fro
m the Project will substantially outweigh the Project costs (including social and environmenta
l costs). Project alternatives that need to be discussed to complete this section include:  
  “no project” alternative; 
  Cable route and landing sites; 
  project operation regime (generation flows); 
  spoil disposal sites;

16 
  quarry site; 
  camps; 
  access road alignment/s; and 
  transmission line alignment. 
  Anticipated Impacts and Mitigation Measures: This section predicts and assesses the Pr
oject’s likely positive and negative direct and indirect impacts to physical, biological, socioec
onomic, and physical cultural resources in the Project’s area of influence. The assessment s
hould be conducted in quantitative terms to the extent possible; identify mitigation measures 
and any residual negative impacts that cannot be mitigated; explore opportunities for enhanc
ement; identify and estimate the extent and quality of available data, key data gaps, and unc
ertainties associated with predictions and specifies topics that do not require further attention
; and examine global, transboundary, and cumulative impacts as appropriate.  
This section should include a standard format matrix that identifies potential impacts on land 
resources, water resources, water quality, air and noise, flora & fauna (terrestrial, 
freshwater, and marine), ecosystem services, climate change, soil, cumulative impacts, 
physical cultural resources, public and community health and safety, and socio-economic 
environment and any other relevant parameters, and rank these impacts in terms of their 
severity and duration.  
Particular focus should also be allotted to the following:  
o  Cumulative River Basin Impacts: The potential for cumulative effects of multiple hydro
electric Projects (existing and foreseen/planned) and other impacts in the same river bas
in should be addressed in the ESIA. Any significant cumulative basin impact/s that the Pr
oject will make a notable contribution to needs to be identified and predicted. Such impac
ts primarily relate to altered river flows, habitat fragmentation and the related effects on a
quatic ecology. Impacts affecting erosion control and sediment management, as well as i
ncremental degradation of provisioning, regulating, cultural, and/or regulating ecosystem
 services should also be assessed. The Consultants should refer to IFC’s Good Practice 
Handbook on Cumulative Impact Assessment and Management: Guidance for the Privat
e Sector in Emerging Markets, and take the opportunity to undertake any additional stak
eholder engagement and consultation efforts needed for the preparation of the ESIA to d
efine, and reach consensus on, the Valued Environmental and Social Components (VEC
) on which to focus a Cumulative Impact Assessment (CIA), and upon which manageme
nt strategies shall be developed and implemented. 
o  Climate Change Related Impacts and Risk: This section should assess the Project’s c
ontributions to climate change through the release of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions 
and avoidance and quantify greenhouse gas emissions. It should also assess the Project
’s physical resilience to climate-related adverse weather events (such as sea-level rise, fl
oods, droughts, storms, landslides) and how this may affect Project operations and perfo
rmance or verify that these have been considered in engineering design.

17 
  Public Consultation and Stakeholder Engagement Process: Consultations and stakehold
er engagement activities undertaken by the Project both to-date and for the purposes of the 
supplementary ESIA studies and findings should be documented. In addition, fresh/new con
sultations will be carried out with local community members and local leaders, knowledgeabl
e people, CSO/NGOs operating in the area (local and international), political representatives
, etc. to document their concerns and to outline how these issues/concerns will be addresse
d within framework of Project.  This should include the development of a stakeholder mappin
g and engagement plan based on the understanding of stakeholder interests, expectations, c
oncerns and influence will be carried out and documented. The Consultant will ensure that th
e information is sex-disaggregated and surveys are conducted in a gender-sensitive manner
. For instance, the surveys will be conducted with both male and female respondents and en
sure adequate representation of female-headed households. Where possible, women-only fo
cus groups will be consulted and gender issues raised as part of the consultations. Context-s
pecific, culturally appropriate and inclusive data collection methods will be applied. Please n
ote that consultation with stakeholders has to continue during Project implementation as nec
essary to address issues related to environmental assessment. The consultation process an
d its results are to be documented and reflected in the ESIA report. 
  Project Environmental and Social Impacts and Risks and Mitigation/Resettlement Acti
on: The Consultant will provide an analysis on the environmental and social impacts and risk
s of the Project and discuss measures to mitigate adverse impacts and risks and enhance e
nvironment and social benefits on the Project affected areas. The following potential environ
mental and social impacts should be considered (but not be limited to) while preparing the E
SIA: 
o  The social impacts linked to communities in the Project area including any/all households
/individuals/entities that will be physically or economically displaced (e.g. including ecosy
stem services impacts) by Project infrastructure or associated facilities; 
o  Households or individuals utilizing the government land, i.e. (i) those with the agreement 
or authorization from the government; or (ii) those who are informally (unauthorized) usin
g the land;  
o  Individual or households whose access to natural resources important to their livelihoods
 (i.e. ecosystem services) will be impaired; 
o  The ESIA must provide the exact location of labor camps, those communities nearest to 
the labor camps and the potential impacts of having influx of workers into the community 
and workers-community interactions; 
o  Whether the Project’s environmental flows (eFlows) are appropriate to maintain ecosyste
m services, aquatic biota, fish migration, river connectivity, water quality, and socio-econ
omic and tourism activities in the dewatered stretches of affected rivers. This should be e
valuated through the use of adequate eFlows assessment methodology and scenarios a
nd consider upstream-downstream migratory connectivity, seasonal flows, fish entrainme
nt, and review of the design of any physical mitigation measures and assessment of their

18 
 adequacy for targeted fish; 
o  Whether the Project will impact on the local fishing and tourism sector; 
o  Impact on aquatic (freshwater and marine) and terrestrial flora and fauna (wildlife) and h
abitats in the Project area including impact on any threatened, restricted-range or protect
ed species/habitats or any other Critical or Natural habitat values. Quantification of impac
ts should be attempted wherever possible. In particular, for habitats, this should include q
uantification of Project direct and indirect habitat loss and degradation on modified, natur
al and critical habitat using an appropriate metric (e.g. Quality Hectares); 
o  Impact linked to potential for sedimentation, erosion and land-slides to occur during each
 Project stage including the potential for river or marine scour and bank erosion leading t
o asset loss; 
o  Impacts associated with the management and disposal of waste throughout Project impl
ementation due to limitations in local capacities and facilities for appropriate waste dispo
sal. Also, the extent to which construction and quarrying will generate noise and vibration
, odor and other nuisance to local communities and sensitive receptors. Impacts and issu
es linked to rehabilitation of burrow pits, disposal sites, and quarries; 
o  Traffic, access and transportation linked impacts; 
o  Occupational health and safety impacts; 
o  Community health, safety and security issues and impact including those linked to influx 
of migrant workforce; 
o  Assessment of gender risks (such as the occurrence of gender-based violence during co
nstruction), of opportunities (such as employment creation during both construction and 
operation of the Project), and of potential negative impact on gender dynamics that may 
affect men and women in Project- area and Company; 
o  Emergency scenarios during construction and operation and potential environmental and
 social impacts; 
o  The presentation of emission savings from the generation of renewable energy; and 
o  Assessment of climate change related risks.  
  Development of Impact Mitigation and Management Plans: The Consultant shall develop
 a comprehensive Environmental and Social Management Plan (ESMP). The plan should rec
ommend a set of mitigation, monitoring and institutional measures to eliminate, minimize or r
educe to acceptable levels of adverse environmental and social impacts and/or maximize so
cio-economic benefits. The ESMP shall include a gender action plan based on the gender as
sessment and recommend mitigation measures on gender gaps to be addressed by the Proj
ect. The Consultant should provide cost outlays for the proposed mitigation measures as wel
l as their institutional and financial support, time frame and responsibility. This shall be provid
ed for all the Project phases.

19 
The Consultant is required to give specific descriptions, and technical details, of monitoring 
measures for the ESMP, including the parameters to be measured, methods to be used, 
sampling locations, and frequency of measurements. The monitoring should be designed to 
assess achievement of specific targets (as appropriate, e.g., No Net Loss of biodiversity), 
definition of thresholds of deviation from these targets that will signal the need for corrective 
actions, as well as deliver a monitoring and reporting procedure that will include assessment 
of progress towards these targets. The Consultant should provide a time frame and 
implementation mechanism, staffing requirements, training and cost outlays. 
  Development of Stakeholder Engagement and Grievance Redress Plan: The Consultant
 should, as a part of the ESIA, undertake stakeholder consultations especially taking into con
sideration the gender concerns and vulnerable groups. A Stakeholder Engagement and Grie
vance Redress Plan should be developed for the Project which would be implemented by th
e Project proponents.  The Stakeholder Engagement plan should: 
o  Identify affected people/groups/communities/civil society organizations (stakeholders); 
o  Delineated measures to allow meaningful engagement with different stakeholder (in a tra
nsparent, accessible manner using culturally appropriate communication methods) so as
 to facilitate dissemination of information to stakeholder;  
o  Suggest differentiated measures to allow effective participation of disadvantaged and vul
nerable groups; 
o  Provide systems for prior disclosure/dissemination of information and consultation includi
ng seeking inputs from affected persons, incorporation of inputs, as applicable, providing
 feedback to affected persons/groups on whether and how the input has been incorporat
ed; 
o  Include mechanisms for feedback and dispute resolution (grievance management and ha
ndling system for the Project); and 
o  Documentation, reporting and monitoring procedures. 
Phase 2b: Social Compliance Audit and/or Resettlement Action Plan Preparation 
Depending upon the status of land availability and arrangement for the Project, the Consultant 
will undertake (either or both): 
  A Social Compliance Audit (SCA) to identify any past or legacy or current issues associate
d with land acquisition and measures required (if any) to ensure compliance to SPS requirem
ents. This will include an onsite assessment to identify past and present concerns related to i
mpacts on involuntary resettlement and indigenous peoples to determine the level of complia
nce with national legislation and SPS SR2 and SR3, and to identify and plan appropriate me
asures to address outstanding compliance issues. Where a non-compliance is identified a co
rrective action plan (CAP) will be developed. The SCA will be a discrete document but appen
ded to the Project ESIA. 
  While it is anticipated that land-related impacts with regard to the main Project components l

20 
and areas leased by the Municipality to the Company will be minimal, the SCA may, if deem
ed necessary in Phase 1, assess the following areas of enquiry against the requirements of 
ADB SR2 and SR3: 
o  Undertake a full replacement cost assessment study describing methods, results and the
 expert opinion whether the compensations paid for affected assets for the Projects repre
sent full replacement costs and thus complying in this respect with ADB SPS SR2 requir
ements; 
o  Obtain information from the Project Sponsor such as inventory of losses, census survey, 
GIS and cadastral information; minutes of meetings or any documentation or records of e
ngagement between the government authority, the affected landowners or users (residen
tial/commercial or any other either directly or indirectly dependent on land or its immovab
le asset) on land acquisition and resettlement; records of evidence of payment made;  
o  Prepare a worksheet presenting the list of affected people, complete information on asse
ts affected and compensated, compensation rate vs amount of compensation paid, any o
ther cash allowance (transition or support); the gap or difference between compensation 
paid and full replacement cost; date paid and outstanding payments;  
o  Identify vulnerable groups and individuals who may be disproportionally affected by the P
roject including those who are at risk of re-establishing livelihoods and/or commercial ent
erprises as a result of the Project;  
o  In case presence and impact to ethnic and sub-ethnic groups is confirmed, review earlier
 engagement with ethnic groups affected by the Project and assess whether such engag
ement complies with the requirements on consent through broad community support as r
equired under ADB’s SPS SR3 on Indigenous Peoples; 
o  Determine any land and ROW acquisition impacts, any adverse environment, community
 health and safety impacts to ethnic minorities in the nearby communities and assess me
asures taken against ADB’s SPS SR3 on Indigenous Peoples; 
o  Develop a Corrective Action Plan (CAP) with follow-up corrective measures and impleme
ntation plan details, parameters and outcome indicators to comply with applicable standa
rds.    
  Where it is found, in Phase 1, that land is or will be acquired in the future specifically for the 
Project the Consultant prepare a Resettlement Plan (RP) or Livelihoods Restoration Plan
 (LRP, if all impacts are found to be related to economic displacement) compliant to SPS SR
2 requirements. This will include a review of all land requirements of the Project, permanent 
and temporary, and identify assets affected during pre-construction, construction and operati
ons phase of the Project. Identify any impacts to assets and livelihoods as a result of environ
mental media in the upstream and downstream of the Project. Identify all forest land, unregis
tered land or state-owned land which fall within the Project footprint and determine if they are
 under productive use by private individuals or communities and assess the potential for eco
nomic or physical displacement. Specific guidance on the requirements for the development

21 
of an ADB compliant RP is available in the ADB SPS 2009. 
4.  DELIVERABLES AND TIMELINE 
It is anticipated that the Consultant will submit the draft Scoping Report within 8 weeks of the date 
of engagement. This Scoping Report is to include a detailed plan with expected timeline for 
completion  of  Phase  2a  and  2b  tasks  and  deliverables.  Timing  of  surveys  and  baseline 
sampling/monitoring should be clearly stated, with reference to local, seasonal conditions.  
 
5.  EXPERTISE REQUIRED 
The  Consultant  should  be  familiar  with  the  Assessment  Framework,  including  gender  and 
development aspects.  Experience working in Fiji, undertaking ESIAs in accordance with ADB 
SPS  and  with  hydropower  development  in  the  Pacific  region  should  be  highlighted.  The 
biodiversity specialists on the team should include appropriate regional taxonomic expertise to 
cover potential high biodiversity risks, including aquatic biodiversity, snails, plants, and birds. 
 
The Consultant should have experts in Social Impact Assessment, Resettlement and Livelihood 
Restoration Planning, Indigenous Peoples and community consultation and engagement. The 
Consultant will include a gender specialist (or at least expertise within the team on gender and 
development) with a proven ability to conduct a gender analysis to ensure gender issues are 
appropriately considered during the assessment, data analysis, recommendation development 
and report writing. Areas of experience need to include gender-sensitive data collection and 
disaggregation, ability to undertake a robust gender analysis and detail a gender action plan, and 
gender-sensitive stakeholder consultations. 
 
The Consultant should have member(s) with local knowledge and language skills.  The team 
composition should also carefully take into consideration mobility to site given specific in-country 
travel requirements, particularly with regard to COVID-19 government travel restrictions. Any 
subsequent change of experts or hiring of additional resource by the Consultant will be with prior 
consent of the Company and ADB. 
 
Due to the wide range of expertise required, use of specialist sub-consultants is encouraged 
on a non-exclusive basis. Roles and responsibilities of the team should be clearly indicated, 
and  CVs  provided  for  all  individuals;  management  of  sub-consultants  is  to  be  clearly 
demonstrated in an organization chart. 
  
6.  FEES 
The Consultant should provide a detailed breakdown of fees by phase and task, noting that the 
extent of work required during Phases 2a and 2b are dependent upon the outcomes of Phase 1. 
All assumptions in this regard should be clearly stated. Expenses should be detailed, and costs 
associated with sampling and laboratory analysis estimated. Hourly rates should be provided for 
all team members, including sub-consultants.

22 
B.  Legal Consulting Services 
 
1.  INTRODUCTION 
 
Hydro  Developments  Pty  Ltd  is  developing  a  mini  hydropower  project  and  an  associated 
transmission system (the Project) aimed at supplying renewable energy to Taveuni and Vanua 
Levu Islands in northern Fiji as an Independent Power Project or IPP. The Project will include mini 
hydropower generating plants with capacities of 4000kW and 2000kW. The larger plant is on 
native land near the villages of Lavena and the smaller one is on freehold land at Salialevu Estate. 
The Project includes 75km of 33kV transmission line and a 9km long submarine to deliver 
electricity  from  Lavena  hydro  plant  via  a  33/11kV  substation  at  Wairiki,  to  a  defined 
interconnection point southwest of Labasa with subsidiary offtake at Wairiki and at Savusavu. An 
66kV transmission line 115km long would deliver electricity from Salialevu mini hydro plant to 
electricity cooperatives and private agricultural consumers in south Taveuni, and also connected 
to Wairiki substation for onward transmission to Vanua Levu. 
 
Through its local subsidiary Hydro Taveuni Pte Ltd, in October 2020 Hydro Developments 
submitted a bid to EFL for the supply of up to 40GWh/year of renewable energy to Vanua Levu. 
In March 2021 the company was selected to sign a non-disclosure agreement with EFL to share 
information  and  to  provide  further  information  on  Project  cost,  and  particularly  that  of  the 
dedicated transmission system needed.  
 
All the proposed works will be subject to engineering feasibility study and to an Environmental 
and Social impact Assessment to be carried out in accordance with Fiji Government law and with 
ADB Safeguards requirements. Following Phase 1 of the feasibility study to be completed in 
September 2021, the Project will be presented to EFL for acceptance after which negotiations 
would commence in relation to a PPA and a possible minor shareholding by EFL in the Project 
company equity. Phase 2 would comprise all additional work to complete the development phase 
and to be ready to start construction by 1 July 2022. 
 
2.  SCOPE OF WORK 
 
The scope of the legal services to be offered includes: 
 
  Phase 2 a): To advise Hydro Developments on: 
o  Electricity Act 2017 provisions for issue electricity of generating licenses to IPP’s by 
FCCC; 
o  Legal  approvals  and  requirements,  including  licenses,  to  build,  own,  operate,  and 
maintain power transmission facilities; 
o  Land leases and easements; 
o  ESIA legal issues; and 
o  A complete list of all other permits and licenses required for the operation of an IPP 
hydropower facility. 
 
 
  Phase 2 b): To further advise Hydro Developments on: 
o  Corporate structuring arrangements; 
o  Drafting and review of Power Purchase Agreement to be entered into with EFL; 
o  Establishment  of  electricity  cooperatives  in  areas  outside  EFL  grid  under  FCCC 
guidelines;

23 
o  Land  lease  arrangements  with  TLTB,  on  freehold  land  and  sub-easements  for 
transmission lines within FRA easements, across freehold land and across native land; 
o  Advice on potential JV or shareholder arrangements in Fiji and assistance with drafting 
of agreements; 
o  Advice on tax incentives available including concessions under Fiji’s Look North Policy; 
o  Assistance with drafting of EPC contracts; 
o  Assistance with review of loan agreements under Fiji Law; and 
o  Any other legal matters affecting the development, construction and operation of the 
Project. 
 
3.  QUALIFICATIONS 
 
The  Project  requires  the  services  of  a  Fijian  law  firm  that  is  familiar  with  the  delivery  of 
infrastructure  and  power  projects  in  Fiji,  with  experience  in  setting  up  development  and 
operational ventures, competent to undertake the work and qualified to provide services for or 
funded by ADB.

24
